channel.title: Thoughts on Java 8

item.title: Thoughts on Java 8
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:67, topic:545349”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=664232.msg4446829#msg4446829 date=1409262640]

Yeah. I noticed this creeping up in Java 7 as well. I think it’s bullshit that users have to change their security settings to run self-signed applications on websites now. Cause unless you have a big name in the computer world, there’s just no other way Java will let your users run it. Kind of bullshit to be honest. Google has started to become more uptight about that too regarding downloads in Chrome.

You can buy a code signing certificate for like $10/yr? And it is a very small price to add on to the start up costs of your server. In most cases one donation will cover that?

If you are serious about being a developer of any kind then you would pay for a signing cert. Not only does it tell people you are serious, but it prevents people from manipulating your files and then trying to pass it off as you.
[/quote]
Where the hell are you finding ones for $10 a year???
http://www.sslshopper.com/java-code-signing-certificates.html
https://www.thawte.com/code-signing/content-signing-certificates/sun-java/[/quote]
Might have aimed a little too low there. Comodo had advertised $80/yr when I was looking earlier but can’t find it anymore. Even $300/yr is less than those sponsored servers pay for one month of being in the top. When you are that large it is definitely worth the expense.

Read full topic

item.description:

gross

item.title: Thoughts on Java 8
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:73, topic:545349”][quote author=tyb97 link=topic=664232.msg4446874#msg4446874 date=1409274875]

Yeah. I noticed this creeping up in Java 7 as well. I think it’s bullshit that users have to change their security settings to run self-signed applications on websites now. Cause unless you have a big name in the computer world, there’s just no other way Java will let your users run it. Kind of bullshit to be honest. Google has started to become more uptight about that too regarding downloads in Chrome.

You can buy a code signing certificate for like $10/yr? And it is a very small price to add on to the start up costs of your server. In most cases one donation will cover that?

If you are serious about being a developer of any kind then you would pay for a signing cert. Not only does it tell people you are serious, but it prevents people from manipulating your files and then trying to pass it off as you.

Where the hell are you finding ones for $10 a year???
http://www.sslshopper.com/java-code-signing-certificates.html
https://www.thawte.com/code-signing/content-signing-certificates/sun-java/

Note: I’m aware this stackoverflow post is outdated

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/155241/cheapest-java-code-signing-certificate-not-self-signed

Nothing near $10.

Yep. I signed up with them and everything. I’ve been generating a key for my file for about 45 minutes now.
Good thing it’s free otherwise I’d be real upset lol.

What are you doing now? I’m lost
[/quote]

I’m generating a private key on the website to be used with my certificate.
It is still generating, by the way.
http://puu.sh/bc9Hj/8e638b318b.png
I realize I could just generate my own key and csr but I didn’t think this shit would be generating for an hour…[/quote]
Generated the key, attempted to import it to my SSL. Key unrecognized. Sigh…

Read full topic

item.title: Thoughts on Java 8
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:72, topic:545349”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=664232.msg4446872#msg4446872 date=1409274551]

Yeah. I noticed this creeping up in Java 7 as well. I think it’s bullshit that users have to change their security settings to run self-signed applications on websites now. Cause unless you have a big name in the computer world, there’s just no other way Java will let your users run it. Kind of bullshit to be honest. Google has started to become more uptight about that too regarding downloads in Chrome.

You can buy a code signing certificate for like $10/yr? And it is a very small price to add on to the start up costs of your server. In most cases one donation will cover that?

If you are serious about being a developer of any kind then you would pay for a signing cert. Not only does it tell people you are serious, but it prevents people from manipulating your files and then trying to pass it off as you.

Where the hell are you finding ones for $10 a year???
http://www.sslshopper.com/java-code-signing-certificates.html
https://www.thawte.com/code-signing/content-signing-certificates/sun-java/

Note: I’m aware this stackoverflow post is outdated

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/155241/cheapest-java-code-signing-certificate-not-self-signed

Nothing near $10.

Yep. I signed up with them and everything. I’ve been generating a key for my file for about 45 minutes now.
Good thing it’s free otherwise I’d be real upset lol.
[/quote]
What are you doing now? I’m lost[/quote]

I’m generating a private key on the website to be used with my certificate.
It is still generating, by the way.
http://puu.sh/bc9Hj/8e638b318b.png
I realize I could just generate my own key and csr but I didn’t think this shit would be generating for an hour…

Read full topic

item.title: Thoughts on Java 8
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

xEthanx:

Yeah. I noticed this creeping up in Java 7 as well. I think it’s bullshit that users have to change their security settings to run self-signed applications on websites now. Cause unless you have a big name in the computer world, there’s just no other way Java will let your users run it. Kind of bullshit to be honest. Google has started to become more uptight about that too regarding downloads in Chrome.

You can buy a code signing certificate for like $10/yr? And it is a very small price to add on to the start up costs of your server. In most cases one donation will cover that?

If you are serious about being a developer of any kind then you would pay for a signing cert. Not only does it tell people you are serious, but it prevents people from manipulating your files and then trying to pass it off as you.

Read full topic

item.title: Thoughts on Java 8
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“xEthanx, post:63, topic:545349”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=664232.msg4446505#msg4446505 date=1409082166]

That’s their problem. Core developments should use the newest versions available to them, the end user client developments should compile with the latest recommended version to support those using the basic JRE that gets updated with the Java Auto Updater.

Yeah, that’s my point.
They haven’t changed the latest recommended version to Java 8.

If you’re saying you shouldn’t upgrade to Java 8 because it isn’t the recommended version, you’re living in the dark.

I’ve already got Java 8. I haven’t used any of the new features (code wise), but the damn security changes are annoying.
[/quote]
Yeah. I noticed this creeping up in Java 7 as well. I think it’s bullshit that users have to change their security settings to run self-signed applications on websites now. Cause unless you have a big name in the computer world, there’s just no other way Java will let your users run it. Kind of bullshit to be honest. Google has started to become more uptight about that too regarding downloads in Chrome.[/quote]
You can add specific websites to a whitelist that will allow self signed apps to run.
However, you have to do it for every site that will have a Jar on it you want to run (that is self signed).

I’m glad they still offered some form of a feature where we can whitelist apps, but I don’t think they should have removed the setting entirely, I think we should have the option to put ourselves at risk (like chrome and downloading).

Read full topic

item.title: Thoughts on Java 8
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“xEthanx, post:63, topic:545349”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=664232.msg4446505#msg4446505 date=1409082166]

That’s their problem. Core developments should use the newest versions available to them, the end user client developments should compile with the latest recommended version to support those using the basic JRE that gets updated with the Java Auto Updater.

Yeah, that’s my point.
They haven’t changed the latest recommended version to Java 8.

If you’re saying you shouldn’t upgrade to Java 8 because it isn’t the recommended version, you’re living in the dark.

I’ve already got Java 8. I haven’t used any of the new features (code wise), but the damn security changes are annoying.
[/quote]
Yeah. I noticed this creeping up in Java 7 as well. I think it’s bullshit that users have to change their security settings to run self-signed applications on websites now. Cause unless you have a big name in the computer world, there’s just no other way Java will let your users run it. Kind of bullshit to be honest. Google has started to become more uptight about that too regarding downloads in Chrome.[/quote]
One can understand their point. Java Drive By’s are so easy to hide in applications and so many people have been affected by fraudulent applets that they added it to help facebook crawlers from getting JDB’d everyday. It helps stop the bad guys but hurts the good guys.

Read full topic

item.title: Thoughts on Java 8
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:54, topic:545349”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=664232.msg4446400#msg4446400 date=1409038838]

It’s fully released…I was reading the notes on nashorn though and things like generators still need to be implemented :C

They still suggest using JRE 7 update 67, however

You only really should heed those suggestions if you’re an enterprise looking to upgrade.
[/quote]
Yeah but that typically means that the average end user will have Java 7 u 67 or lower, since they don’t care to update java let alone get versions that are newer than recommended.[/quote]
That’s their problem. Core developments should use the newest versions available to them, the end user client developments should compile with the latest recommended version to support those using the basic JRE that gets updated with the Java Auto Updater.

Read full topic
